supporting.text: Aspirin is classified as a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), not an antiviral, as it primarily reduces inflammation, pain, and fever.

attacks.text: Aspirin is classified as a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), not an antiviral, as it primarily reduces inflammation, pain, and fever.
Some studies suggest aspirin may have indirect antiviral effects by modulating the immune response during viral infections.
These indirect effects are not sufficient to classify aspirin as an antiviral drug, as they do not directly target viral replication.
Aspirin has been observed to reduce viral load in certain cases, such as in dengue fever.
The observed effects in dengue are not generalizable to other viruses and do not meet the standard criteria for antiviral classification.

supporting.text: Antiviral drugs specifically target viral replication mechanisms, whereas aspirin has no known direct effect on viral life cycles.

attacks.text: Antiviral drugs specifically target viral replication mechanisms, whereas aspirin has no known direct effect on viral life cycles.
Aspirin has been shown to reduce inflammation caused by viral infections, indirectly affecting viral replication by modulating the host immune response.
Modulating the host immune response is not the same as directly targeting viral replication, which is the defining feature of antiviral drugs.
Some studies suggest aspirin may inhibit certain viral enzymes, indicating a potential direct antiviral effect.
The evidence for aspirin directly inhibiting viral enzymes is limited and not widely replicated, making it an unreliable basis for classification as an antiviral drug.

supporting.text: Clinical use of aspirin is focused on cardiovascular health and pain relief, with no approved indications for treating viral infections.

attacks.text: Clinical use of aspirin is focused on cardiovascular health and pain relief, with no approved indications for treating viral infections.
Some studies suggest aspirin may have indirect antiviral effects by reducing inflammation that worsens viral infections.
These indirect effects are not clinically significant enough to classify aspirin as an antiviral drug.
Aspirin has been used historically during pandemics like the 1918 flu, suggesting perceived antiviral utility.
Historical use was primarily for symptom management, not actual viral suppression.

supporting.text: Scientific consensus and drug databases categorize aspirin separately from antiviral medications due to its distinct pharmacological properties.
